Seven prospective dual meets and
two major intercollegiate track
events appear in the spring track
schedule for 1928, as released last
Friday by Ridgely Edwards, coach
of the Hopkins team. Several of
the colleges included have not definitely closed with the Hopkins mentor, but it is practically a certainty
that no additions to the present
schedule will be made later in the
season. One of the meets, that with
Randolph-Macon College, is at present very uncertain.
Three home meets and probably
a fourth appear in the list, while
three will be away. The teams
scheduled to be met on Homewood
Field are: Maryland, the University of Richmond, Gettysburg, and
very probably Delaware. The Old
Liners will journey here at a very
early date (April 14), because no
Other satisfactory date could be
agreed upon by the two teams.

Thursday, December 24, will be
the date for the Almanac Number
of the Black and Blue Jay to appear
on the campus. According to members of the staff this issue will be
among the best ever published. The
cover by Bill Banks will be an innovation done in black and white.
Another novelty will be found on
the editorial page, which will be divided into twelve parts, one for each
month. The heads for these parts
have been drawn by John Eldridge.
Everything is in readiness for the
third issue, all copy for it having
been handed in. The circulation department expects 3000 copies to be
printed. One more issue will appear before the mid-year's, a regular number to be published in January.

NEW BOOK ISSUED
BY HOPKINS PRESS
"State Security and the
League of Nations" is the title
of a book by Dr. Bruce Williams, professor of political
science of the University of
Virginia, which has -just been
published by the Hopkins
Press.
This survey of the movement for State security from
the Treaty of Versailles of the
Locarno Conference is made
up of the Albert Shaw lectures on diplomatic history
which were delivered at Hopkins by Dr. Williams last
winter.

characteristic burst of speed during
the last lap. Dick Gwinn, who had

winter.

Large Squad

Coach George Darley appeared at
this time. When questioned, he expressed himself as well pleased with
the size of the squad, which, he
pointed out, exceeded the number
of football candidates. He deplored

facilities, calling attention to the
fact that the team could only practice twice a week and has started

time in which to work.
"However," he added in a most
optimistic tone, "the boys are showing remarkably good spirit. They
are really trying to make a go of it.

and it's encouraging to see so many
